description: 15th century. Borrowed from Scots glint; from Middle English glenten (“to shine, gleam; flash”); probably alteration of Old Norse [Term?]; from Middle High German glinzen; from Proto-Germanic *glintaną, *glintjaną; from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰley- (“to shine”). Cognate with Swedish glänta, glinta (“to slip, slide, gleam, shine”), Swedish glimt. Reintroduced into literary English by Robert Burns.

adjectives.description: glint (comparative more glint, superlative most glint)

entries.meaning: (archaic, Shropshire, of a blade) Not sharp; dull.

examples: I saw the glint of metal as he raised the gun.

verbs.description: glint (third-person singular simple present glints, present participle glinting, simple past and past participle glinted)

examples: A wedding ring glinted on her finger.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To glance; to peep forth, as a flower from the bud; to glitter.
examples: The rising sun owre Galston muirs, / Wi' glorious light was glintin'

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to flash or gleam; to reflect.
examples: The scientists theorized that a meteoroid, ranging in size from a speck of dust to a marble, might have struck the satellite and chipped off a bit of debris that glinted a ray of sun back on the Vela's second sensor  […]

entries.meaning: (archaic, Shropshire, transitive) To dry; to wither.
examples: The sun glints grass and corn.
